specJson.name: brightics.function.timeseries$arima_train
specJson.label: ARIMA Train
specJson.description:
ARIMA(Auto-regressive Integrated Moving Average) is a generalized model of ARMA(Auto-regressive Moving Average) which explains present data by using past observed values and errors. Moving average means a trend that average of data changes as time goes by. A main difference between ARIMA and ARMA is that ARIMA reflects momentum of previous data as well as using the data from past. Therefore, ARIMA considers not only correlation but also cointergration. 

ARIMA is usually used to monitor if there is abnormal value on trend by reviewing data on a weekly/monthly basis or to predict future values on a quarter/yearly basis. A strength of ARIMA compared to ARMA is it can be adapted to data which shows non-stationary series. Stationary series is a type of series which average and variance are unchangeable regardless of time transition. In case of non-stationary series, it is normally analyzed after stabilizing it with log or difference.

params.label: Input Columns
params.description: Input column names. Only values in numeric type are possible.

params.label: p
params.description: The order (number of time lags) of the autoregressive model.

params.label: d
params.description: The degree of differencing (the number of times the data have had past values subtracted).

params.label: q
params.description: The order of the moving-average model.

specJson.summary: This function trains a time series data using an ARIMA model.

md: # ARIMA Train This function trains a time series data using an ARIMA model. ## Description ARIMA(Auto-regressive Integrated Moving Average) is a generalized model of ARMA(Auto-regressive Moving Average) which explains present data by using past observed values and errors. Moving average means a trend that average of data changes as time goes by. A main difference between ARIMA and ARMA is that ARIMA reflects momentum of previous data as well as using the data from past. Therefore, ARIMA considers not only correlation but also cointergration. ARIMA is usually used to monitor if there is abnormal value on trend by reviewing data on a weekly/monthly basis or to predict future values on a quarter/yearly basis. A strength of ARIMA compared to ARMA is it can be adapted to data which shows non-stationary series. Stationary series is a type of series which average and variance are unchangeable regardless of time transition. In case of non-stationary series, it is normally analyzed after stabilizing it with log or difference. Reference - - ## Properties ### VA #### INPUT 1. **table***: (Table) Training data in a Table. It must contain at least one column for time series data. #### OUTPUT 1. **model**: (Model) Trained ARIMA Time Series model. #### PARAMETER 1. **Input Columns***: Input column names. Only values in numeric type are possible. 2. **p***: The order (number of time lags) of the autoregressive model. 3. **d***: The degree of differencing (the number of times the data have had past values subtracted). 4. **q***: The order of the moving-average model. 5. **Intercept**: The trend parameter. 6. **Group By**: Columns to group by. ### Python #### USAGE ``` arima_train(table, input_cols, p, d, q, intercept=True, group_by=None) ``` #### INPUT 1. **table***: (Table) Training data in a Table. It must contain at least one column for time series data. #### OUTPUT 1. **model**: (Model) Trained ARIMA Time Series model. #### PARAMETER 1. **input_cols***: Input column names. Only values in numeric type are possible. * Type: *list[str]* 2. **p***: The order (number of time lags) of the autoregressive model. * Type: *int* * Default / Range: (value >=0) 3. **d***: The degree of differencing (the number of times the data have had past values subtracted). * Type: *int* * Default / Range: (0 <= value <= 2) 4. **q***: The order of the moving-average model. * Type: *int* * Default / Range: (value >=0) 5. **intercept**: The trend parameter. * Type: *bool* * Default value: True 6. **group_by**: Columns to group by. * Type: *list[str]* ## Example ### VA **[Related Tutorial]** **[Sample Model]** In this tutorial workflow, sample_timeseries data is used to train a ARIMA model. The generated model is afterward applied to predict the _future value at certain time point_ by using ARIMA Predict function. The parameter settings used in the function are shown below. ++Parameters++ 1. **Input Columns***: data2 2. **p***: 3 3. **d***: 0 4. **q***: 2 5. **Intercept**: True 6. **Group By**: None ### Python ``` from brightics.function.timeseries import arima_train input_table = inputs[0] result = arima_train(table=input_table, input_cols=['data2'], p=3, d=0, q=2, intercept=True, group_by=None) output = result['model'] ``` In this python script, sample_timeseries data is used to train a ARIMA model. The generated model is afterward applied to predict the _future value at certain time point_ by using ARIMA Predict function.
